Root Cause: Vault used manipulable Curve pool prices; no oracle/slippage protection.
Vault relied on manipulable Curve 3pool pricing, allowing flash-loan price distortion.
Collateral values could be inflated via flash-loan price manipulation of Uniswap pools used for lending valuations.
A reentrancy flaw in the bonding curve contract allowed attackers to repeatedly withdraw funds.

The protocol used an AMM-based oracle for asset price feeds — this oracle could be manipulated (via flash loans), allowing the attacker to inflate asset prices and drain liquidity from the lending pool.
Protocol relied on manipulable AMM pricing (Curve) for collateral valuation; no safeguards against flash-loan-driven price swings.
Missing reentrancy guard in the SavingsModule contract allowed repeated liquidity additions before state updates.

A vulnerability in the mint logic of the OUSD vault (VaultCore) — lack of reentrancy protection and improper validation of incoming assets caused inflation of totalSupply and allowed draining of underlying assets.
Protocol relied on manipulable Uniswap/Kyber AMM prices for collateral valuation with no safeguards against flash-loan-driven price manipulation.
Blacksmith contract allowed repeated reward withdrawals without proper accounting, enabling infinite COVER token minting.
Strategy contract trusted external Jar addresses without validation, allowing a malicious “Evil Jar” to redirect vault funds.
Incorrect signature/authorization validation allowed attackers to trigger unauthorized withdrawals from user-linked vesting contracts.
Cross-chain bridge contract allowed attacker to forge messages and change “owner” via incorrect verification logic.
Initialization function could be called again, allowing attackers to withdraw pool assets without depositing.
The AMM used a custom “power()” function (for non-50/50 pools) copied from another project; incorrect input assumptions (baseN < baseD) allowed attackers to exploit the invariant and drain liquidity.
Incorrect debt accounting allowed users to mint alETH without locking collateral.
Attacker tricked the system into treating a malicious contract as a legitimate Aave contract, abusing authorization logic.
Unauthorized access allowed attacker to mint synthetic assets and withdraw protocol funds.
An outdated oracle price was reused to mint undercollateralized synthetic assets.
Incorrect authentication in cross-chain bridge allowed unauthorized minting of bridged tokens.
Incorrect share-calculation logic allowed attacker to withdraw far more LP tokens than deposited via vault misconfiguration.
Double-counting bug in the reward calculation enabled attackers to mint excessive ZABU tokens.
AutoShark’s JAWS token minting logic allowed attackers to manipulate price feeds and mint excessive tokens.
Incorrect accounting in “FarmingStrategyV2” let attacker withdraw more funds than deposited by manipulating the reward/debt calculation.
Incorrect reward minting logic allowed attackers to mint unlimited SPACE tokens.
Minting logic in the PolyBunny bridging contract allowed unauthorized creation of PolyBUNNY tokens due to improper access validation.
Faulty price-per-share and reward accounting in the auto-compounder vault allowed withdrawals that exceeded the attacker’s proportional deposit.
Incorrect handling of Cream’s ibBTC integration allowed attacker to drain Alpha’s funds via multi-step flash-loan manipulation.
Faulty liquidity share calculation in AMM pools allowed attacker to remove more liquidity than they contributed.
Price manipulation of dYdX’s xSNX strategy and flawed reward accounting allowed attacker to drain collateral.
Price manipulation of MINT/MOR token pools allowed attacker to mint improperly valued collateral using flash loans.
Complex manipulation of Curve 3Pool pricing combined with Yearn’s vault accounting allowed attacker to profit from repeated deposit/withdraw cycles.
Flawed minter/admin role allowed attacker to directly manipulate token balances across staking pools.

The pool valuation logic used a flawed “extrapolatePoolValueFromToken” formula which depended on a single token’s balance/weight; by manipulating token balances (via flash loans), the attacker caused massive mis-valuation, minted inflated index-tokens, and withdrew disproportionate underlying assets.
Price manipulation of stablecoin pools allowed attacker to borrow synthetic assets with insufficient collateral.
4Belt pool had faulty accounting in the “belt strategy” that let attacker manipulate virtual balance calculations using flash loans.
Price manipulation of BNB/USDT on PancakeSwap caused protocol to mint excessive BUNNY tokens to the attacker.

The protocol used a single on-chain oracle (via Pangolin) for pricing; attacker manipulated newly created token-pair prices to bypass slippage and price checks — combined with incorrect price-calculation logic, enabling draining of funds.
Price manipulation + flawed collateral accounting enabled attacker to borrow massive amounts using repeated flash-loan cycles.
Custom AMM swap logic allowed attackers to create fake tokens and manipulate reserve balances to steal liquidity.
Grim’s depositFor() lacked a reentrancy guard, allowing attacker-controlled vault tokens to re-enter during deposit and duplicate shares.
A flaw in AMP token’s ERC777 implementation allowed reentrancy via tokensReceived(), enabling attackers to borrow repeatedly from CREAM Iron Bank.
Flawed internal accounting allowed attacker to withdraw more BUSD than deposited by manipulating the vault’s withdraw logic.
Incorrect minting logic in the SDO stablecoin allowed infinite issuance via flawed reward mechanism.
Reward and share accounting miscalculated user shares, allowing attackers to withdraw more liquidity than deposited through manipulated entry/exit cycles.
Price calculation bug in the liquidity withdrawal logic allowed attacker to drain LCDOT liquidity from Karura DEX.
A flaw in the constant-product invariant (k value) check allowed attackers to execute malicious swaps and drain liquidity without proper balance validation.
A compromised private key controlling the pNetwork validator allowed the attacker to forge peg-out events and mint unbacked pBTC on BSC.

The vSwap AMM used a custom power()‐based formula for weighted pools; when pools had non-50/50 asset ratios, this formula failed, allowing the attacker to exploit the wrong invariant to drain liquidity.

A governance upgrade (Proposal 062) introduced an incorrect calculation in the Comptroller’s reward distribution module (DistributorV2), causing users to receive excessive COMP tokens when claiming rewards.
Incorrect price-per-share and reward accounting enabled attacker to withdraw more than their shares justified.
A mistake in the swap fee logic (0.003 → 3) in the AMM math allowed attacker to drain liquidity pools.
Inbound transaction validation in the ETH Bifrost misinterpreted fake ERC20 transfer calls as legitimate asset deposits, causing real ETH to be released.
Integration with Alpha Homora contained a missing reentrancy guard allowing attacker to drain Rari’s ETH pool.
A reentrancy vulnerability in the AMM options pool contracts allowed the attacker to recursively withdraw funds before internal balances were updated.
ETH Bifrost incorrectly validated inbound ERC-20 transfers, treating fake deposits as genuine, leading to unauthorized ETH payouts.
A flaw in MonoX’s token swap smart contract allowed attacker to inflate MONO token price and use it to drain other assets.
Attacker manipulated tick account data to trick concentrated liquidity pools.
NFTs were listed for essentially zero due to improper validation, enabling attackers to steal assets.
A minting logic flaw enabled attackers to create unlimited CASH stablecoins without backing.
Private keys were sent to the wrong address during OP token distribution, enabling misuse.
A batch call vulnerability allowed attackers to manipulate super tokens and drain funds.
Incorrect handling of wrapped assets enabled attackers to mint unbacked tokens.
A flawed reward contract allowed attackers to withdraw excess funds.
An attacker manipulated the liquidity pool price oracle during routing transactions.
A DNS attack redirected users to a malicious frontend that drained funds.
A staking helper contract allowed unauthorized privilege escalation.
The attacker acquired majority governance voting power through flash loans and passed a malicious proposal.
An attacker manipulated the price oracle via a flash loan to drain the treasury.
The attacker manipulated the price oracle for the DEI stablecoin by exploiting Solidly TWAP pricing.
Attackers manipulated the price of plvGLP collateral, allowing excessive borrowing.
A mint-price oracle flaw allowed attackers to mint ANA at an undervalued price and sell it higher.
Attackers manipulated INV/USD pricing to borrow assets, exploiting a vulnerable oracle feed.
A reentrancy vulnerability in token contracts allowed recursive borrowing.
Same attacker as Agave used reentrancy in hTOKENS to drain funds.
A malicious contract repeatedly invoked the MasterChef withdrawal function.
A reentrancy vulnerability in Fuse pools allowed recursive withdrawals.
Attacker manipulated liquidity pool pricing to borrow against inflated collateral.
Incorrect accounting in the swap contract allowed attackers to drain pool imbalance.
A price oracle flaw in XFT collateral enabled borrowing far beyond the correct value.
A flaw in the governance contract allowed attackers to pass a malicious proposal to withdraw treasury funds.
A flawed migration function allowed attackers to move tokens in unintended ways.
Improper validation allowed attackers to mint unbacked XFTM tokens.
LUNA crash caused stale price oracles, allowing attackers to borrow against worthless collateral.
Attacker inflated MNGO price using illiquid markets, then borrowed large sums.
Attacker artificially inflated MOO price to borrow large amounts of other assets.
Attacker manipulated AVAX spot pricing via external CEXs to profit from GMX perps.
Attackers manipulated the INV token oracle to borrow DOLA and USDT.
A faulty accounting logic caused liquidity imbalance enabling asset withdrawal.
The protocol relied on a manipulable LP-token price oracle for the sBTC–WBTC pool; the attacker manipulated this price to artificially inflate collateral value and drained pool assets.
A compromised or incorrectly verified proof allowed the attacker to forge a withdrawal message and mint 2M BNB.
A faulty redemption formula allowed attackers to withdraw more than their fair share during token redemption.

The flash function lacked reentrancy protection: attacker took out flash-loan, called deposit() in the callback, making contract believe loan repaid while allowing LP tokens withdrawal, effectively draining the pool.
A reentrancy flaw in token wrappers allowed recursive calls to borrow assets from the lending pool without proper validation.
An attacker targeted a vulnerability in the FNFT contract registry, allowing unauthorized withdrawals.
Attackers used a fake deposit message to trick the bridge contract into minting unbacked qXETH.
A flaw in the routing contract allowed arbitrary external calls with user-supplied parameters.
A faulty initialization set the committed root to 0x00, enabling anyone to submit valid-looking proofs and withdraw funds.
A vulnerability in the liquidity pool contract allowed an attacker to remove liquidity due to an unintentionally public burn function.
The attacker exploited admin privileges to withdraw locked lending pool funds.
A compromised API/private key allowed attackers to withdraw significant amounts of liquidity.
Attackers exploited a flawed internal call that allowed unauthorized token transfers.
The Maestro router contract allowed arbitrary transferFrom calls, letting attackers drain any token previously approved by users.
A bookkeeping flaw allowed attackers to over-withdraw NFT-backed loans.
A vulnerability in the DEI stablecoin redemption logic allowed minting of unbacked tokens.
A mistakenly duplicated market token allowed attackers to withdraw excess funds.
Attackers breached Mixin’s cloud service provider database, enabling unauthorized fund withdrawals.
A flawed rate-calculation mechanism allowed attackers to inflate collateral and drain funds.
A compromised deployer key allowed unauthorized modification of vault configurations.
Attacker inflated the value of collateral assets to borrow more than allowed.
A manipulated vGHST price allowed attackers to borrow heavily against inflated collateral.
Incorrect donation logic in the soft-liquidation mechanism allowed the attacker to drain assets using leveraged liquidations.
A manipulated exchange rate for hTOKENS allowed attackers to borrow more than their collateral justified.
A misconfigured yVault (legacy vault) allowed minting yUSDT with drastically incorrect conversion rates.
A business-logic flaw in the liquidity pool contract allowed attackers to manipulate internal accounting using improper transfer and skim interactions, enabling unauthorized fund extraction.
A compromised deployer wallet enabled unauthorized upgrades and fund withdrawals.
An attacker manipulated LP-based price feeds to mint unbacked bridge tokens and drain liquidity.
A manipulated Curve LP oracle allowed attackers to drain funds from omnipools.
A faulty liquidation mechanism allowed attackers to borrow without correct solvency checks.
Attackers manipulated yield-bearing asset prices to drain liquidity via over-borrowing.
A voting-escrow and solvency check flaw allowed attackers to drain pools using zero-collateral borrowing.
A reentrancy flaw in the liquidation callback allowed attackers to drain vault balances.
The attacker manipulated the token price through thin liquidity, enabling over-borrowing against inflated collateral.
Liquidation parameters were exploited using manipulated pool pricing via flash loans.
A critical vulnerability in certain V2 “boosted pools” — due to incorrect pool logic — allowed attackers to drain funds.
Attacker exploited oracle desynchronization during liquid staking withdrawals.
A miscalculation in the PlpManager contract allowed incorrect USDP valuation during flash-loan execution, enabling pool drainage.
A privileged function lacked proper access checks, allowing unauthorized control over trading pools.
The attacker manipulated asset pricing through a weak TWAP oracle, enabling under-collateralized withdrawals via force-investment mechanics.
A vulnerable route processor contract enabled unauthorized token transfers.
An incorrect oracle price for tGMX allowed the attacker to borrow against inflated collateral.
Flash-loan amplified Curve pool imbalance enabled stealth withdrawal of stablecoins.
API key compromise enabled unauthorized margin position liquidation and withdrawal.
Attacker manipulated the ALBT price oracle to mint unbacked BONQ and drain liquidity.
A vulnerable liquidation threshold allowed infinite leverage buildup.
Collateral pricing errors enabled attackers to borrow beyond safe limits.
A rounding-error in the redeem / interest-rate calculation allowed the attacker to exploit the redemption logic and withdraw more than rightful share.
A reentrancy vulnerability in the exchange router’s swapThroughOrionPool / depositAsset logic — attacker used a malicious token + flash-loan to deposit, re-enter, and withdraw inflated balance.
A reentrancy vulnerability in the wrapped ETH token allowed recursive borrow-withdraw loops.
A reentrancy vulnerability in a lending market contract allowed recursive withdrawals before balance updates.
A reentrancy vulnerability in the share trading smart contract allowed recursive withdrawals before balances were updated.
A compromised private key allowed unauthorized minting and draining of protocol funds.
An attacker manipulated the price feed used for perpetual positions, enabling risk-free profit extraction.
The claim-function contract failed to properly enforce that a signature could be used only once; the attacker reused the same valid signature multiple times to repeatedly claim tokens.
A suspected multisig or validator key compromise enabled unauthorized cross-chain withdrawals.
A router contract vulnerability allowed attackers to drain user-approved tokens via arbitrary transfer calls.
A vulnerability in the Hedera Token Service precompile enabled attackers to mint unbacked liquidity pool tokens.
A privileged authority key was abused, enabling unauthorized fund withdrawals from protocol-controlled accounts.
A reentrancy vulnerability in multiple Vyper-compiled contracts enabled repeated drainage of liquidity pools.
A vulnerability in certain V2 boosted pools enabled attackers to drain funds due to incorrect pool logic.
A vault accounting logic flaw enabled attackers to mint excess stablecoin shares and drain liquidity.
Incorrect liquidation accounting allowed attackers to extract excess collateral during margin close-outs.
A hot-wallet breach exposed private keys controlling multiple assets.
Unauthorized access to withdrawal infrastructure enabled mass fund extraction.
Private keys of at least 3 out of 11 multi-sig signers were compromised via a malware-based social-engineering attack, allowing the attacker to approve and execute unauthorized transactions.
A lower-security SMS-based verification routine allowed attackers to whitelist malicious withdrawal addresses.
The exitPool function lacked permission checks, allowing anyone to impersonate a liquidity provider and drain the pool.
An uninitialized smart contract allowed attackers to seize control and drain token balances.
A vulnerability in the withdrawal function allowed attackers to drain liquidity pools without proper balance validation.
Attackers exploited permission issues in the smart contracts of the defunct protocol to withdraw remaining locked funds.
An infinite approval vulnerability in the AgentToken.sol bonding contract enabled attackers to drain bonding curve funds.
Oracle desync between Curve LP and MIM vault enabled under-collateralized borrowing.
Improper vesting signature validation enabled repeated unauthorized unlocks.
Illiquid asset pricing allowed attackers to inflate collateral for leveraged borrowing.
A vulnerability in the newly upgraded v1 farming contracts allowed the attacker to withdraw excessive liquidity pool tokens.
A compromised deployer wallet allowed unauthorized contract ownership transfer.
A reentrancy flaw in the callback router enabled recursive swaps and balance inflation.

A known vulnerability in forks of Compound V2 was not patched: new market parameters (c-factors) were scheduled via a timelock, but the attacker inserted themselves as first executor once timelock expired — enabling them to manipulate collateral valuations and drain lending pools.
A logic flaw in a newly deployed market allowed attackers to use flash loans to mint and drain assets without proper collateral validation.
A freshly launched USDC market had empty reserves, allowing attackers to manipulate the liquidity index and borrow unbacked assets.
The attacker manipulated price oracles and solvency checks using flash loans to borrow against inflated collateral.
The protocol relied on spot pricing of BOO token pairs; the attacker manipulated BOO price to borrow against massively inflated collateral value.
The attacker manipulated on-chain token pricing through a thin-liquidity pool used as a price oracle, enabling over-borrowing and fund drainage.
A vulnerability in the MigrateTroveZap contract allowed attackers to manipulate the migration process and siphon protocol funds.
A vulnerability in the Telegram message handling allowed attackers to trigger unauthorized ETH transfers from active users.
Attackers compromised guardian-based 2FA accounts and transferred assets from affected wallets.
A previously patched IBC-Hooks reentrancy vulnerability was accidentally reintroduced in a later upgrade and exploited.
A flawed token price calculation combined with unrestricted minting logic allowed attackers to inflate token supply and drain liquidity using flash loans.
The attacker gained control of a privileged admin wallet and minted 5 billion GALA tokens.
An infinite mint vulnerability allowed the attacker (a former developer) to arbitrarily mint 1B HLG tokens and dump them.
A decimal-precision rounding bug inherited from Compound V2 allowed attackers to drain low-liquidity markets.
A faulty post-upgrade implementation allowed attackers to execute unauthorized withdrawals.
A flaw in the re-hypothecation and accounting logic of the uniBTC vault enabled asset over-minting and withdrawal.
A flawed Wormhole bridge message verification allowed unauthorized withdrawals from the SmartBridge contract.
The attacker exploited a contract breach to arbitrarily mint CVG tokens from the reward distributor and offload them.
A compromised API key allowed attackers to execute unauthorized token transfers from user routing contracts.
Malware on team systems led to private key compromise of staking contracts, enabling unauthorized token transfers.

Vault deposit logic allowed extreme price swings (50–200% price-change threshold) on certain vaults. By manipulating the price via flash-loan/price-feed abuse, attacker minted inflated LP shares and withdrew disproportionate assets.
The attacker manipulated oracle pricing through thin-liquidity pools to extract excess assets.
A price oracle misconfiguration allowed the attacker to massively inflate collateral value and drain protocol liquidity.
A reentrancy vulnerability in the _burn() function of the Rebalancer contract enabled repeated withdrawals.
A reentrancy flaw in vault reward distribution logic allowed recursive withdrawals of deposited assets.
A reentrancy vulnerability combined with a flash-loan allowed attackers to bypass collateral accounting.
A reentrancy vulnerability in the project’s locking smart contracts enabled repeated asset withdrawals.
A reentrancy vulnerability in the project’s locking smart contracts enabled repeated asset withdrawals.

Blockchain: Ethereum, Polygon, BNB Chain, Avalanche, Arbitrum, Optimism, Base
Root Cause: A vulnerability in the MagpieRouterV2 contract allowed unauthorized token transfers from connected wallets.
A liquidation accounting bug allowed attackers to withdraw more collateral than permitted.
A malicious insider with privileged access directly transferred protocol treasury funds.
An attacker manipulated the valuation of collateral tokens via flash loans to borrow excess assets.
A compromised admin key was used to mint unbacked tokens and drain liquidity pools.
